webTitle: Triple boost for UK economy as data shows signs of recovery

fields.standfirst: Rises in factory output, car sales and house prices add to hopes that Britain is emerging from the post-recession doldrums
fields.body:
Hopes that Britain has finally emerged from its post-recession doldrums received a triple boost with news of surging factory output, higher car sales and rising activity in the housing market.

Fresh signs that the economy may achieve the "escape velocity" sought by Mark Carney, the new governor of the Bank of England, was provided by data covering industrial output and the two biggest ticket items of consumer spending.

The Office for National Statistics said an across the board increase saw manufacturing production grow by 1.9% in June following declines in both April and May.

Over the three months to July – a better guide to the underlying trend – UK factory output was up 0.7%. Industrial production, which includes North Sea oil production and output from the domestic energy sector, was up 0.6% over the same period.

Meanwhile, the Halifax, the UK's biggest mortgage lender, reported a 0.9% jump in house prices in July amid evidence that government schemes were encouraging buyers back into the market.

Martin Ellis, Halifax housing economist, said: "House prices in the three months to July were 2.1% higher than in the previous three months. This is similar to the rates of increase recorded throughout the first six months of 2013. Prices in the three months to July were 4.6% higher than in the same three months last year, the highest annual rate since August 2010. Sales have also picked up with total purchase transactions for the first half of the year 6% higher than in the same period last year.

"Signs of improvement in the economy, underlined by the recent evidence of a rise in gross domestic product in the second quarter and increases in employment, appear to have boosted consumer confidence. Greater confidence is likely to have underpinned the increase in housing demand. Official schemes, such as the Funding for Lending Scheme and the Help to Buy equity loan scheme, may also be raising demand. House prices are expected to continue to rise gradually through this year with only modest economic growth and still falling real earnings constraining housing demand and activity."

The Society of Motor Manufacturers and Traders, the trade body for the UK automotive industry, raised its growth forecast for 2013 following figures for July showing that 162,228 vehicles were sold during the month, a rise of more than 12% on July 2012 and the 17th successive monthly increase.

"Strong business and consumer confidence in July saw the new car market continue to rise, posting double-digit growth in the month. Now we have evidence of consistent growth, we have raised our forecast for 2013 new car registrations to 2.216m units, an increase of over 8% on last year," said Mike Baunton, SMMT interim chief executive. Previously, the SMMT had been predicting sales growth of 3% in 2013, but Baunton said: "Recently, we've seen a range of economic indicators point to improving conditions and our raised sales forecast emphasises how positively we view the rest of 2013."

Tuesday's upbeat news comes after data on Monday showing Britain's dominant services sector enjoyed its best month since before the financial crisis, smashing economists' forecasts for July and boosting hopes the recovery is gathering pace.

The UK services PMI index jumped to 60.2 in July from 56.9 in June, against forecasts of just over 57. The July reading was the highest since December 2006, when Britain was booming but less than a year before the run on Northern Rock signalled the arrival of the credit crunch.

webTitle: Interest rates cut to 2.5% by Reserve Bank - live blog

fields.standfirst: As expected, the official cash rate falls from 2.75% to 2.50% - the lowest official interest rate for over 50 years
fields.body:
6.52am BST

Summary

Time for a bit of a recap:

• As expected the RBA cut the rates to 2.5%, as low as official rates have been since before Elvis joined the Army.

• NAB, Bank of Queensland, Commonwealth Bank have quickly come out and said they will pass on rate in full. This gets mortgage rates down to 43 year lows.

• The RBA’s statement was relatively positive (as positive as a central bank gets when economic growth is below trend). They indicate that there is scope for cutting rate further, but the general sense is we won’t see that happen till November (on Melbourne Cup Day).

I shall sign off now. Thanks for everyone for reading and commenting.

6.47am BST

The Commonwealth Bank has also announced it will pass on the rate cut in full.

6.47am BST

Treasurer Chris Bowen now speaking:

He starts with the John Howard’s old “record lows” line, and then points out the difference between now and November 2007.

For the record - the average mortgage rate was 8.55% (now 5.95%)

The average term deposit rate was 6.75% (the last month it was 3.90%).

Chris Bowen is now onto standard political argy bargy - cuts to the bone and so forth.

Updated at 6.48am BST

6.35am BST

The issue with interest rates cuts is that when rates get down to this low, you have to wonder just what impact they will have.

Is there really anyone out there who was thinking of buying a house, but was thing, “Nah I’ll wait till they get lower than they have been in the past 43 years?”

If you weren’t going to buy a house at 6.2%, chances are you probably won’t at 5.95%, so it’s not like this will supercharge the economy. It will however give people more money to save/spend (so long as they don’t like many do, just keep paying the same amount each month).

I don’t think there’s much point in going lower, and instead perhaps looking at ways to get banks lowering rates to businesses.

6.28am BST

The issue of course is not just mortgage rates. The big sticking point has been small business loan and overdraft rates.

Currently, the non-secured overdraft rate for small businesses is 9.20%. The rate did go down the full amount with the last rate cut, so here’s hoping banks pass on the full amount to businesses as well.

Their rate of 9.20% is not that far below the 10.45% it was in December 2007, despite the cash rate being 4.25 percentage points lower.

The problem is the GFC meant banks became much more risk averse - and small businesses are riskier than home loans. This is one of the reason why the drop in the cash rate hasn’t had the same impact on investment in the economy as you would normally expect.

6.19am BST

It’s pretty clear every bank will pass on the cuts in full. To not do so would be to give their competition a pretty pointless advantage.

The ANZ of course waits until Friday to make its decision, so those holding a mortgage with them will have to wait.

6.16am BST

The Bank of Queensland has also passed the rate cut in full

Updated at 6.17am BST

6.13am BST

Average mortgage rates

OK, here’s a bit of a nerdy graph - the average mortgage rates going all the way back to February 1959.

The current average rate of 5.95% was beaten for eight months during the GFC in 2009. That was a real emergency period. But outside such an unusual period (and nothing the RBA says in its statement suggests they think we are in an “emergency”) the last time they were this low was March 1970 when they were 5.88%

The lowest rates have ever got is 5.0%, all the way back in 1963-64 and in 1959-60.

Updated at 6.15am BST

6.04am BST

One of the statements Joe Hockey has been making recently about interest rates is that the average of mortgage rates under the Howard government is lower than they have been under the ALP since December 2007.

Well the average of mortgage rates under John Howard was 7.26%. With this latest cut (and assuming all other banks follow the NAB and cut by the full 25 basis points), the average rate under the Rudd and Gillard governments is now 7.27%.

It might be time to end these silly arguments of who has the lowest interest rates.

Updated at 6.07am BST

5.58am BST

The market seems to have taken the RBA’s statement as being positive. The dollar “jumped” from US$0.8924 to US$0.8965.

So OK, not the biggest of all jumps, but nearly half a cent.

Although it is worth bearing in mind that dealers on the foreign exchange market do get a bit jumpy (some serious caffeine intake I think). When the last inflation figures came out, the first reaction on the market was for the dollar to go up, because there was an instant belief they meant the RBA would not cut rates.

Clearly that didn’t happen.

5.53am BST

And now for the RBA’s conclusion:

The Board has previously noted that the inflation outlook could provide some scope to ease policy further, should that be required to support demand. At today's meeting, and taking account of recent information on prices and activity, the Board judged that a further decline in the cash rate was appropriate. The Board will continue to assess the outlook and adjust policy as needed to foster sustainable growth in demand and inflation outcomes consistent with the inflation target over time.

This is pretty neutral - but there does appear to be the suggestion that they could go lower if they were of a mind.

5.52am BST

The National Australia Bank will cut rates to 5.88%

Other than briefly during the GFC, the last time mortgage rates were that low was in March 1970.

Updated at 5.54am BST

5.50am BST

Stephen Koukoulas, the Managing Director of Market Economics, a macroeconomic advisory firm Advisor to Dun & Bradstreet tweets:

5.48am BST

Now the RBA turns to the housing market and the exchange rate:

The easing in monetary policy over the past 18 months has supported interest-sensitive spending and asset values, and further effects can be expected over time. The pace of borrowing has remained relatively subdued, though recently there are signs of increased demand for finance by households.

The Australian dollar has depreciated by around 15 per cent since early April, although it remains at a high level. It is possible that the exchange rate will depreciate further over time, which would help to foster a rebalancing of growth in the economy.

The only difference between these two paragraphs and what was written in July is that in June the depreciation of the dollar was 10%.

The RBA seriously loves using cut and paste.

5.45am BST

Good comment from below the line.

5.44am BST

The RBA’s view of the domestic economy is much as it was last month:

In Australia, the economy has been growing a bit below trend over the past year. This is expected to continue in the near term as the economy adjusts to lower levels of mining investment. The unemployment rate has edged higher. Recent data confirm that inflation has been consistent with the medium-term target. With growth in labour costs moderating, this is expected to remain the case over the next one to two years, even with the effects of the recent depreciation of the exchange rate.

And once again the RBA has failed to note any wages breakout. The lack of wage inflation is one of the biggest failures of those critics of the current Industrial Relations legislation.

Updated at 5.47am BST

5.42am BST

OK so why did they do it, let’s have a look at the statement by the Governor.

Firstly they note:

Recent information is consistent with global growth running a bit below average this year, with reasonable prospects of a pick-up next year. Commodity prices have declined but, overall, remain at high levels by historical standards. Inflation has moderated over recent months in a number of countries.

A pretty dour start to things but no change really from last time.

Indeed most of the statement is word for word the same as last time - even though last time they kept rates steady

5.36am BST

What does a rate cut mean to mortgage holders?

Well for an average mortgage of $300,000 it’s a saving of around $46 a month, for a mortgage of $400,000 the saving is about $62 a month - if your bank passes on the full cut. They did last time, and there really isn’t a lot of reason why they wouldn’t do so again. Their funding costs haven’t risen significantly, and they have been lowering the rate offered for deposits.

The average six month term deposit for deposits over $10,000 has fallen since April from 3.80% to 3.15%

5.34am BST

Announcement

And the Reserve Bank has now made it official - the cash rate has been cut by 25 basis points to 2.50%.

5.29am BST

Righto, here we go...

If the RBA does keep rates on hold, it will be very interesting to see how they justify it. The market generally doesn’t like being wrong..

5.20am BST

Where do Australian interest rates compared to the rest of the world?

Our interest rates are at record lows, but we’re not alone on that score, and we’re certainly not the lowest.

The official Fed rate in the US is 0.13% and it has been at that level since December 2008 (now that really is a sign your economy is struggling).

Japan’s official rate is even lower - 0.10%, but this is actually above the 0.05% rate they had for two years until it was raised in April this year.

The UK and coincidentally the Euro area have rates at 0.50%, while Canada has rates at 1.0%

5.17am BST

The Labor Party

The problem for the Government is that the economy is certainly not booming. The Economic Statement released last Friday by the Treasurer, predicts the unemployment rate to reach 6.25% in 2014-15.

Now mortgage holders might like low interest rates, but they also like having a job, and it’s tough to sell the line that things are going ok, when your own figures predict they will get worse.

The reason the RBA can lower rates is because as Treasurer Wayne Swan did actually cut spending. In 2012-13 he cut Government spending from $371 bn in 2011-12 to $367.3 bn. That was the first time in over 40 years that a government has spent less in a year than it did in the previous one.

This policy effectively meant the RBA had to do all the heavy lifting to try and stimulate the economy.

That we are now likely to hit 2.5% shows just how much lifting they have had to do. That the unemployment rate is predicted to get to 6.25% makes you wonder whether perhaps cutting spending so dramatically was a good way to go about helping the economy.

5.09am BST

The other problem is that for much of the past five years Mr Hockey has suggested the government's debt and deficit have been putting upward pressure on interest rate. In September 2010, for example, he noted:

The likelihood of interest rates rising is back on the agenda, following explicit warnings from the Reserve Bank that it is considering the need for tighter monetary policy.

The Coalition has consistently warned that the Labor Government’s heavy borrowing and build up of debt will put upward pressure on interest rates.

The RBA did increase rates two months later to 4.75%, but that was as high as they went. Since November 2011 they have only been falling.

The Liberal Party now has to reconcile the old line of debt and waste being bad because it leads to higher interest rates with the current one of debt and waste being bad because it leads to interest rates being cut.

5.04am BST

What is the politics of this cut?

The Liberal Party

Remember when low interest rates were what every political party promised? Now it seems that is no longer such a great thing.

The Liberal Party, long-time champions of the “Interest rate will always be lower...” line, now have tried to change the issue to one that suggests interest rate cuts are a sign of a poor economy. This morning on the ABC’s AM, Joe Hockey said

And lower interest rates are always good when you have a trend or above trend growth, not falling growth as occurs under Labor. You would want to have rising employment, falling unemployment - not the reverse, which is rising unemployment as is now the case under Labor.

The problem for Mr Hockey is that the last time there was an interest rate cut under the Howard Government was December 2001. From that time till November 2007 the cash rate rose from 4.25% to 6.75%.

Updated at 5.07am BST

4.59am BST

What other things will the RBA will be looking at?

The RBA always keeps a close eye on the state of consumer spending - on retail and housing.

Then on Monday, the Retail Sales figures showed retail spending had grown by an anaemic 0.1% in June. As noted here last month, spending on restaurants and take-away food remains the only growth area, while spending in departmental stores and clothing and retails stores has actually declined in the past year.

The annual rise of all retail spending of just 2.1% is the lowest since August 2011.

This morning the most recent housing price data saw the average of housing price in the capital cities rise 5.1% in the past year. It has been steadily increasing for the past six months, so if the RBA does cut rates today, it is likely to be the last cut for a while.
